div.sent: There are a lot of peculiar and various matters in the world.
Actually all these diverse objects are composed of some fundamental substances.
The Indian philosophers also considered fire and sky as the fundamental substances.
However, modern science has proved that fire or sky are not matters at all, and water, air and soil are not any fundamental substances.
The British scientist Cavendish proved that water is not an elementary substance; it is composed of two gaseous elements- oxygen and hydrogen.
You have learnt about the three states of matters solid, liquid and gaseous.
In whatever states a matter exists, the scientists have divided the matters into two main categories such as element and compound.
Elements: An element is a substance which cannot be broken or split up by chemical analysis into two or more simple and dissimilar substances.
Hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, carbon, sulphur, copper, zinc, mercury, gold, silver etc. are the examples of elements.
Until now 111 elements have been discovered in the world.
Out of these 92 elements occur in nature while the remaining elements have been artificially prepared by scientists in the laboratory.
At normal condition most of the elements are solid, 5 are liquids and 11 elements are gaseous.
Iron, copper, zinc, gold, silver, sulphur, aluminium, tin, carbon, phosphorous, silicon etc. are the examples of solid elements.
Mercury, Bromine, Gallium, Caesium and Francium are liquid elements while Hydrogen, Nitrogen, Chlorine, Fluorine, Helium, Neon, Argon, Krypton, Xenon, Radon etc. are the gaseous elements.
Compounds: A compound substance consists of two or more elements.
Water, Sugar, Soap, Soda, Salt, Carbon dioxide, etc. are the examples of compounds.
The number of elements is limited but the number of compounds is unlimited.
Every day a number of new compounds are being formed.
As a result, the number of compounds is increasing day by day.
In ancient times the Indian philosopher Konad and the Greek philosopher Democritus raised questions about the formation of countless substances in the world.
Konad named this minute particle atom.
Atom means indivisible i.e. which cannot be broken down further.
About 2000 years later, in 1803, the British mathematician and natural scientist John Dalton put forward a new idea about atom.
He said that each element is composed of its smallest particles.
The smallest particles of an element are called its atoms.
The smallest particle of the element, which keeps its own identity.
It takes part in the chemical reaction and on further division loses its own identity completely.
The tiniest particle is called atom.
All the substances in the world are composed of atoms.
Atoms cannot be seen even by the very powerful microscopes.
If 10 crores of atoms are placed side by side the length of them will be nearly half an inch or 1.25 centimetres only.
The 111 elements have 111 different atoms.
An atom of each element has its own mass and properties.
Again the atoms in an element are all alike.
For example, hydrogen element is composed of only hydrogen atoms; oxygen contains only oxygen atoms and iron contains only iron atoms.
It is also possible to divide an atom under special condition.
Atomic energy is generated by breaking the atoms.
The idea about given by the scientist John Dalton is known as Dalton's Atomic theory.
Elements are composed of very minute indivisible particles called atom.
Atoms of an element are similar in property and mass.
The atoms in hydrogen are all alike, same in mass and property.
Similarly, each iron atom has the same mass and property.
The atoms of different elements are different in their property and mass.
Accordingly the atoms of hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, sulphur, gold, silver, iron, etc. are different from one another in their mass and properties.
There are no similarities between the properties of gold and silver or between those of hydrogen and oxygen.
The atoms of different elements combine with one another in simple numerical proportion to form a compound.
Scientist John Dalton first established this theory regarding atoms.
That is why this theory is called Dalton's atomic theory.
Molecule: According to the scientists all matters in this world are composed of minute particles.
At this stage the smallest particle of the substance, which can exist in free state, is called molecule.
Dalton could not predict how the particles of compounds are formed.
During the time of Dalton, there were controversies among the scientists regarding the independent existence of elementary gases like hydrogen, oxygen etc. in nature.
rather, they remain as a combined particle of two atoms.
He named these particles as molecule.
The meaning of the word molecule is heap or pile that is a combination of more than one atom.
That is a union of two or more atoms.
After 40 years of Avogadro's death, one of his students Cannizaro proved that the theory about molecule is true.
Usually a molecule contains more than one atom.
Two or more atoms combine together to form a molecule.
There are two types of molecules: elementary molecules and compound molecules.
When two or more atoms of the same element combine to form a molecule, it is called elementary molecule.
The molecule of an element or a compound is composed of atoms always in a definite proportion.
The elementary gases like hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, chlorine, etc are diatomic.
But neon, argon, etc are monatomic.
On the other hand a compound molecule such as water consists of two atoms of hydrogen and one atom of oxygen.
Therefore, you must have understood that a compound is formed by the chemical combination of two or more atoms of different elements.
If we split the smallest particle of a compound, it does not retain its properties;
it is split up into the elements that formed it.
When water is split up, it is divided into its component atoms hydrogen and oxygen.
Water is an example of a compound.
The molecules of oxygen, hydrogen, etc. are the elementary molecules while carbon dioxide molecule is a compound molecule.
The molecule of a carbon dioxide is a compound molecule.
It is composed of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms.
Brick, wood, chair, table, coal, stone, iron, metal, etc. are solid substances.
Solid has definite shape and size.
Solid does not change its shape and size at normal condition.
By this time we have known that all substances are composed of the countless molecules of that substance.
In solids, the molecules are close together with a very great force of attraction making a lump.
There is almost no space between the molecules.
That is why the shape and size of solids cannot be changed easily by exerting pressure.
Liquid: A liquid has a fixed volume but no fixed shape.
A liquid takes the shape of a container in which it is kept.
Experiment: Take a round bottom flask, a beakerand and a glass jar.
Take 100 ml water in each container.
Though the sameamount of water is taken in each container, water takes different shapes in different container.
Water, oil, milk, petrol etc. are examples of liquid.
Liquid is also an aggregate of molecules.
But in this case the particles are loosely held together having some space between the molecules.
Owing to this liquid takes the shape of a container in which it is kept.
But its volume remains unchanged.
Gaseous substance: A gas has no definite shape and volume.
The molecules of a gaseous substance tend to go away in any direction.
Air is a gaseous substance.
So, air spreads all over the world.
The substance which has no definite shape or volume and which spreads freely all over its surrounding is called gas or a gaseous substance.
The gaseous substance also consists of molecules.
But in gas, molecules exist freely from each other in sheltered conditions.
That is, in a gas the molecules stay far away from one another.
So the attractive force between the molecules is almost negligible and they tend to go away in any direction.
For this reason the container is kept closed when the gas is put in it.
The gas will go out if there is a small hole in the container.
Solids have definite shape and volume.
Molecules in solids are very close to each other.
There is no space among the molecules.
There is a powerful force of attraction among the solid molecules.
Liquids have a definite volume but no definite shape.
The molecules of liquids are held loosely together.
There is a small space among the molecules.
The force of attraction in liquid molecules is less than that in solid ones.
Gas has no definite volume and shape.
The molecules of gas are far away from each other.
The force of attraction among the gaseous molecules is almost negligible.
Every molecule of a substance has its own shape.
A substance consists of an aggregate of molecules.
Molecules are arranged side by side in the substance.
Due to this there are some spaces among the molecules.
For example, if some marbles are staked together, there will be some spaces among the marbles.
There are similar spaces among the molecules.
They are called intermolecular space.
A nail can be penetrated into wood because of intermolecular spaces.
When we try to penetrate a nail into wood, the molecules of wood get closer to one another making room for the nail.
For this the volume of the substance is also reduced.
Again, when the pressure is reduced, the intermolecular spaces increase; as a result the volume increases.
Similarly, the molecules of substances become more kinetic after being heated and intermolecular spaces increase among the molecules.
So, the volume of the substance increases when they are heated.
Again, as the heat is reduced or the substance cools down, it volume decreases and so do the intermolecular spaces.
Experiment 1: Take some copper sulphate or blue vitriol powder in a beaker and fill the beaker with water carefully.
Allow the contents settle down.
Experiment 2: Keep the small container of a perfume keep on a table with its lid open.
What do you observe in the above experiment?
Is there any change in the water of the beaker?
Does the water in the beaker have the same colour throughout?
Both copper sulphate and perfume are composed of molecules.
The molecules of perfume spread out through air, and the molecules of copper sulphate in the water spread out in all directions.
This is because the molecules have motions and they can move.
There is a force of attraction working among the molecules of a substance.
It does not allow them move away from one another; it holds them together.
The force of attraction that exists among the molecules is called the intermolecular force.
However, there is a repulsive force among the molecules due to which they tend to move away from one another.
The resultant force of these two opposite forces is called the intermolecular force.
Intermolecular force is very powerful in the solid state.
The molecules of solid body get close to one another with a great force and cannot change positions even in motion or from vibration.
They vibrate continuously remaining in their positions.
This enables the solid to have a definite shape and volume.
In liquid, intermolecular force is weaker than that of solid.
In liquid, molecules exist a little apart from one another, and they can move independently.
Hence, the liquid has a definite volume but no fixed shape.
The intermolecular force in a gas is almost negligible.
For this reason, the gas has no definite shape and volume.
If a small quantity of gas is put in a big container, it spreads throughout the container and fills it.
This happens because of the intermolecular force among the molecules.
The molecule with the properties of smell spread out through air and first reach the people nearby and then to others at a distance.
Changes in speed of the molecules and transformation of bodies due to heat.
We can change the state of matters which are a vailable in nature as solid, liquid and gas by increasing or decreasing temperature.
If we heat solid ice slightly, it Structure of Matter, Atom and Molecule 11 changes to water.
When water is boiled, it changes to steam.
Again when steam cools, it is changes to water; if it cools further, it becomes ice.
Thus transformation of matter takes place with the change of temperature.
The transformation of matter At normal temperature the molecules of a solid vibrate continuously in their respective positions.
Heat gives them excess energy and they begin to vibrate.
As a result they moveHeat away from one another.
On being further heated the intermolecular spaces are increased due to a decrease in intermolecular force and the molecules are allowed to move freely.
In this condition, solid changes to liquid.
Thus a liquid changes to steam.
A reverse process takes place when the gaseous substances are cooled;
the velocity of the molecules decreases and they come close to one another.
As a result, the intermolecular space decreases and intermolecular attraction increases.
If the substance cools further, the intermolecular force increases to such an extent that the gas changes to liquid.
When the liquid is cools further, the molecules come closer to one another and the intermolecular space decreases to a great extent.
As the temperature decreases, the motion of the molecules also decreases resulting in the increase of intermolecular force.
The liquid finally becomes solid.
In this way, the motion of the molecules of a substance as well as its state is changed by heat.
